A way to process and manage nuclear data that isn't painful. The same thing for output.

Python interfaces/bindings for common codes used by nuclear engineers. To name a few:
MCNP(X), SCALE, SERPENT, CASMO, SIMULATE, RELAP5, REBUS, ERANOS

@paul_romano Also, let me add ORIGEN to your list.

The trick here is we don't want to distribute those codes so bindings should be dynamically-linked.  A couple of fun issues have cropped up here with my Serpent bindings: 

1) Python's main() function takes precedent over executable's main, even on import.

2) Same issue with global variables such as err, out, wrn...
Some sort of health physics package.
Also, I have historical data for all US reactors that lives at https://github.com/scopatz/FuelLearning
I'd be happy with just sharing some pre-/post-processing scripts to get at all the data in a reliable way - as a start.
@gonuke Hey Paul, nice to see that you made it on here ;)  Do you have any code specifically that, with some munging, would be appropriate here?
We also have Perl for parsing PARTISN output
My group has scripts for loading MCNP mesh tallies, but they are currently only Matlab <spins grogger>
Oh, Perl... I used to use it, before I fell madly in love with Python.
never fear, @sethrj , you can have both... you probably know this, but there are a few perl interpreting modules for python... here's one ...  http://search.cpan.org/~gaas/pyperl-1.0/perlmodule.pod
@katyhuff: lol... I did not know that. It's an abomination. :P I love Perl's built-in regex capabilities, but Python's `re` module is respectable enough.
@sethrj It has got to be better than RPy2 ;)
.... methods to convert material definitions from engineering descriptions to lists of isotopes, suitable for choosing cross-sections.
